pullRequest.body:
This PR adds some normal forms of elliptic curves by characteristic. The results are from Silverman's GTM106 second edition, section III.1, page 42, and Appendix A, Proposition 1.1.

- Normal form of characteristics not 2: `Y^2 = X^3 + a_2X^2 + a_4X + a_6`.
- Normal form of characteristics not 2 or 3: `Y^2 = X^3 + a_4X + a_6`. This is also the normal form of characteristic = 3 and j = 0.
- Normal form of characteristic = 3 and j not 0: `Y^2 = X^3 + a_2X^2 + a_6`.
- Normal form of characteristic = 2 and j = 0: `Y^2 + a_3Y = X^3 + a_4X + a_6`.
- Normal form of characteristic = 2 and j not 0: `Y^2 + XY = X^3 + a_2X^2 + a_6`.

Basic properties and the existence of the change of variables to change a curve into these forms are included.

Legendre normal form and Deuring normal form may be added in this file in the future PRs.

---

> Do you intend to add a lot more to this file (e.g. characteristic 2, characteristic not 2 or 3

Yes, My first plan is to add four normal forms with respect to characteristics, listed in Silverman's GTM106. In later PRs we may eventually add Legendre forms, etc.

> maybe the isomorphism on the group of points)? If that's the case, do you think you can repurpose this into a file about isomorphisms induced by variable changes (maybe `Equiv.lean`?).

Not yet, at least not in this PR and in this file. They should be in another (upstream) file anyway.

> A while ago, you added quite a bit of stuff on variable changes that's sprinkled everywhere in `Weierstrass.lean`, but maybe it's time to extract them into a separate file.

I agree, maybe the basic property of variable changes should go to `VariableChange/Basic.lean`. In this way it imports minimal files. In my opinion, the isomorphism of points induced by variable changes should go to a downstream file, since it imports more files.

> Arguably, the main content of this file is the variable change rather than the Prop, unless you have something else you want to prove for the Prop?

No, I think the main contents of this file `NormalForms.lean` are these Props and their corollaries (for example, what is the `j`-invariant, listed in Silverman's GTM106, section III.1 and Appendix A), together with the existence of variable changes (explicit, if applicable, but only merely existence does not harm) to transform a Weierstrass equation to these forms.

:v: acmepjz can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

> My main suggestion is to rename `IsCharNeTwoThreeNF` (either to `IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF`, or to your own custom name, maybe even `IsShortNF`?).

I think `IsShortNF` is better, since it is the normal form of 2 cases, one is char not 2 or 3, another one is char 3 and j = 0.
LGTM! Thanks for your patience

Thanks for the review!

bors r+
Oh I didn't actually check the `@[simp]` tags you added later, but I trust that you made them work somehow.

> Oh I didn't actually check the `@[simp]` tags you added later, but I trust that you made them work somehow.

In fact very few of them were added, as there are a lot of `not in simp normal form` error: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11160554198/job/31021240436. Perhaps some of the `@[simp]` tags should be removed since they didn't simplify things significantly; we can remove them later if it is indeed the case.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11186491772/job/31101624126)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11186491772/job/31101623720)

Thanks! Some minor nitpicks on the docstring, but otherwise LGTM

bors d+

Thanks for this! I added some very basic comments. I note that this is somewhat similar to the `ModelsWithJ` section in `Weierstrass.lean` in the sense that you defined explicit forms of Weierstrass curves for specific purposes.

Do you intend to add a lot more to this file (e.g. characteristic 2, characteristic not 2 or 3, and maybe the isomorphism on the group of points)? If that's the case, do you think you can repurpose this into a file about isomorphisms induced by variable changes (maybe `Equiv.lean`?). A while ago, you added quite a bit of stuff on variable changes that's sprinkled everywhere in `Weierstrass.lean`, but maybe it's time to extract them into a separate file. Arguably, the main content of this file is the variable change rather than the Prop, unless you have something else you want to prove for the Prop?

Thanks! Some minor nitpicks on the docstring, but otherwise LGTM

bors d+
This became a pretty long PR as itself, but the definitions and theorems are very structured with good docstrings :) I added a few basic comments and will go in-depth tomorrow.
Had almost no time today! Some minor suggestions.

Thanks for your patience! I added lots of mostly stylistic comments for the first half. My main suggestion is to rename `IsCharNeTwoThreeNF` (either to `IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF`, or to your own custom name, maybe even `IsShortNF`?). I will finish the second half tomorrow.
Some docstring comments. I will finish the rest tomorrow (I swear!)
Thanks for your patience! I'm happy with this PR once all the changes are made.

```suggestion
/-- A `WeierstrassCurve` is of normal form of characteristic ≠ 2, if its `a₁` and `a₃` coefficients are zero.
```
Also: should it be "in normal form" instead of "of normal form"?
Thanks! Fixed.

What do you think of abbreviating this name as follows:
```suggestion
structure IsNormalForm₂ [Zero R] : Prop where
```

A question is that this is the normal form of characteristic not equal to 2. There are also normal forms of characteristic not equal to 2 or 3, characteristic equal to 2, and characteristic equal to 3. The `IsNormalForm₂` confuses the characteristic not equal to 2 case and characteristic equal to 2 case.

But I admit that this name is too long. Do you think `IsNFCharNeTwo` or `IsNFCharNe2` is OK?
I like `IsNFCharNeTwo` better, but maybe `IsCharNeTwoNF` is more grammatical? Same goes for `IsCharTwoNF` and maybe `IsCharNeThreeNF` for char not 2 or 3 (unless you prefer `IsCharNeTwoThreeNF`)?
I think `IsCharNeTwoNF` is good.
Hmm I've never needed to do `include` before. Does making `IsNormalFormOfCharNeTwo` a typeclass help?
It is a "feature" introduced in [4.11.0](https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/releases/tag/v4.11.0). In fact I'm refrained from making it as a typeclass...

Untested:
```suggestion
    (W.variableChange W.variableChangeToNormalFormOfCharNeTwo).IsNormalFormOfCharNeTwo := by
```

Untested:
```suggestion
variable {W} [CommRing R] (self : W.IsNormalFormOfCharNeTwo)
```
This seems a bit long a name for a common variable change. Maybe you can move it into the `VariableChange` namespace or the `IsNormalFormOfCharNeTwo` namespace and think of a shorter name?

I intended to make it in `WeierstrassCurve` namespace. In this way we can write the dot notation `W.variableChangeToNormalFormOfCharNeTwo`. Of course it is indeed a long name.

After adopting `IsCharNeTwoNF`, it can be shorten as `variableChangeToCharNeTwoNF`. But is it still too long? What about `vcToCharNeTwoNF`?
Is it easy to add the lemma for the `j`-invariant here? I guess you'd need `W` to be an elliptic curve first...
It is possible, but it seems that the formula for `j`-invariant is not simple enough for this case, so I haven't add it yet.

```suggestion
/-! ### Normal forms of characteristic different from two -/
```

```suggestion
- `WeierstrassCurve.IsCharNeTwoNF` is a predicate that asserts that a `WeierstrassCurve` is of form
```
also elsewhere

```suggestion
The following normal forms are in [silverman2009], section III.1, page 42.
```

```suggestion
  this is equivalent to j = 0), then there exists a change of variables which will change
```
also elsewhere
Some of these should be in the `EllipticCurve` namespace (at least for now, before we decide to make `EllipticCurve` a predicate). Probably add the variable `(E : EllipticCurve R)` here to be clear?

> Some of these should be in the `EllipticCurve` namespace (at least for now, before we decide to make `EllipticCurve` a predicate).

No, they are in `WeierstrassCurve.IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF` namespace. This enables the use of dot notation, e.g. `self.j_of_char_three` later, where `self` is `E.IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF` (which in fact is `E.toWeierstrassCurve.IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF`). This works even for current `WeierstrassCurve -> EllipticCurve` API design.

> Probably add the variable `(E : EllipticCurve R)` here to be clear?

`E : EllipticCurve R` is used in different namespaces/sections, so I put it at the beginning of the file.
There are a couple of places where you put `≠ 2`, `not equal to 2`, `different from 2`, etc. in the docstrings --- can you make this consistent? I'm happy with any of them
OK, will stick to `≠ 2`.
Perhaps `toCharNeTwoNF` is fine? I haven't used `vc.*` anywhere in `Weierstrass.lean`, and `variableChangeToCharNeTwoNF` is a bit long. I think `WeierstrassCurve.toCharNeTwoNF` sounds fine.
Good idea.
I don't think `_spec` is very descriptive --- perhaps something like `toCharNeTwoNF_isCharNeTwoNF`?

This name comes from [Classical.choose_spec](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Init/Classical.html#Classical.choose_spec), [Nat.find_spec](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Find.html#Nat.find_spec), [minpolyDiv_spec](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Minpoly/MinpolyDiv.html#minpolyDiv_spec), etc. It means that something satisfies its desired property. In my opinion this naming is shorter and uniform; using `toXXX_isXXX` you need to change to `XXX`s for each different variable changes.

Untested:
```suggestion
  linear_combination -16 * W.a₄ * CharP.cast_eq_zero R 3
```
and same for the others below.
Good idea. Yes it works in existing file `Weierstrass.lean`.

```suggestion
theorem toCharThreeNF_spec : (W₁.variableChange W₁.vcToCharThreeNF).IsCharThreeNF := by
```

```suggestion
theorem toCharTwoNF_spec [DecidableEq K] : (W₁.variableChange W₁.vcToCharTwoNF).IsCharTwoNF := by
```

```suggestion
lemma toCharThreeJZeroNF_a₂ : (W.variableChange W.toCharThreeJZeroNF).a₂ = W.b₂ := by
```

```suggestion
  simp_rw [toCharThreeJZeroNF, toCharNeTwoNF, variableChange_a₂, inv_one, Units.val_one, b₂]
```

```suggestion
theorem toCharNeTwoThreeNF_spec : (W.variableChange W.toCharNeTwoThreeNF).IsCharNeTwoThreeNF := by
```

```suggestion
theorem toCharNeTwoNF_spec : (W.variableChange W.toCharNeTwoNF).IsCharNeTwoNF := by
```

Unsure about this: is `Type*` weaker than `Type u` and `Type v` for explicit universes `u` and `v`? I try to make them as general as possible so far. I think I encountered some issues when trying to use `Type*` in the number field files.

For my projective/Jacobian files I tend to stick with `W' : WeierstrassCurve R` for Weierstrass curves over rings (instead of `W₁` and `W : WeierstrassCurve F` for Weierstrass curves over fields (because I wanted to reserve `K` for specific fields like number fields or finite fields), but feel free to ignore this since this is a different file.

> Unsure about this: is `Type*` weaker than `Type u` and `Type v` for explicit universes `u` and `v`?

`Type*` is the same as `Type u` and `Type v` as long as you don't need to specify universe levels manually. Each `Type*` will be interpreted as distinct universe levels, for example, `{R K : Type*}` means that `R : Type u_1` and `K : Type u_2`. The issue occurred when you want some of these objects are in the same universe level, or if you want to mention the level manually (for example, Cardinal.lift, max of universe levels, e.g. in [lift_rank_mul_lift_rank](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Dimension/Free.html#lift_rank_mul_lift_rank)).

> For my projective/Jacobian files I tend to stick with `W' : WeierstrassCurve R` for Weierstrass curves over rings (instead of `W₁` and `W : WeierstrassCurve F` for Weierstrass curves over fields (because I wanted to reserve `K` for specific fields like number fields or finite fields), but feel free to ignore this since this is a different file.

I see. In fact the name `W₁` is for laziness. Ideally I should use `W` for all `WeierstrassCurve`.

A more genuine question: is there a point in using `structure` rather than just making this a `def`? You have five instances of `structure` and two instances of `def` for `IsChar.*`, and we should probably make this consistent.

I personally prefer `def` since we don't need `_spec`, but maybe there's a reason you need `structure`.

> A more genuine question: is there a point in using `structure` rather than just making this a `def`?

Of course, for example I can use `def IsCharNeTwoThreeNF := W.a₁ = 0 ∧ W.a₂ = 0 ∧ W.a₃ = 0`. But then it's not straightforward to reference `W.a₁ = 0`.

> You have five instances of `structure` and two instances of `def` for `IsChar.*`, and we should probably make this consistent.

Do you mean `inductive IsCharThreeNF : Prop` instead of `def IsCharThreeNF : Prop := W.IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF ∨ W.IsCharNeTwoThreeNF`? Not that this condition is `or`, not `and`. But I think `inductive` version does not give us advantages.

> I personally prefer `def` since we don't need `_spec`, but maybe there's a reason you need `structure`.

I don't get your point. The `_spec` is for the property of the variable change `toCharNeTwoNF`, but not for the prop `IsCharNeTwoNF` itself. So either `def` or `structure`, we always need the `_spec` to state that `toCharNeTwoNF` indeed satisfies the desired property.
Ah fair enough, this was my mistake because I was scrolling too quickly.
The `1` in `linear_combination 1 *` is unnecessary.

This `simp_rw` (and in fact, all the `simp_rw`'s in your file, except for `toCharThreeJZeroNF_a₂`) can be made into an `rw`, and you can make this one long line:
```suggestion
  rw [WeierstrassCurve.Δ, self.b₂_of_char_two, self.b₄, self.b₆_of_char_two, self.b₈_of_char_two]
```

```suggestion
  constructor <;> simp
```

```suggestion
/-- A `WeierstrassCurve` is in normal form of characteristic = 2 and j = 0, if its $a_1, a_2 = 0$.
In other words it is $Y^2 + a_3Y = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$. -/
```

Otherwise it won't link correctly in the docs:
```suggestion
It is the composition of an explicit change of variables with `WeierstrassCurve.toCharNeTwoNF`. -/
```
Oops. Then I think a lot of places need to be changed.

```suggestion
$Y^2 = X^3 + a_2X^2 + a_6$ (`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF`) or
$Y^2 = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$ (`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharNeTwoThreeNF`). -/
```

```suggestion
there is an explicit change of variables of it to `WeierstrassCurve.IsCharThreeNF`, that is,
$Y^2 = X^3 + a_2X^2 + a_6$ (`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF`) or
$Y^2 = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$ (`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharNeTwoThreeNF`).
It is the composition of an explicit change of variables with
`WeierstrassCurve.toCharThreeJZeroNF`. -/
```

```suggestion
(`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharTwoJZeroNF`) if its j = 0. -/
```

```suggestion
(`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharTwoJNeZeroNF`) if its j ≠ 0. -/
```

```suggestion
$Y^2 + XY = X^3 + a_2X^2 + a_6$ (`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharTwoJNeZeroNF`) or
$Y^2 + a_3Y = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$ (`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharTwoJZeroNF`). -/
```

```suggestion
(`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharNeTwoThreeNF`) if its j = 0.
This is in fact given by `WeierstrassCurve.toCharNeTwoNF`. -/
```

```suggestion
there is an explicit change of variables of it to `WeierstrassCurve.IsCharTwoNF`, that is,
$Y^2 + XY = X^3 + a_2X^2 + a_6$ (`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharTwoJNeZeroNF`) or
$Y^2 + a_3Y = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$ (`WeierstrassCurve.IsCharTwoJZeroNF`). -/
```

Do you think it's better to call this (and the others) `CharNeTwoNF`, so that `toCharNeTwoNF` makes more sense? I'm aware that the naming convention for `Prop`'s is to start with a verb so feel free to ignore this!

Another suggestion: if you made this into a `class`, then you can include this into the typeclass system, and you can delete all of the `self.*` in the lemmas below.

> Do you think it's better to call this (and the others) `CharNeTwoNF`, so that `toCharNeTwoNF` makes more sense? I'm aware that the naming convention for `Prop`'s is to start with a verb so feel free to ignore this!

I prefer `Is` version, since `CharNeTwoNF` is a little bit misleading: this name suggests that the data itself in a normal form...

> Another suggestion: if you made this into a `class`, then you can include this into the typeclass system, and you can delete all of the `self.*` in the lemmas below.

I'm not sure about this. Dot notation can't be used for `class` approach, and you need to write long names and `haveI`s...

Do you need long names and `haveI`'s? At least in this file, except for `IsCharThreeNF`, I replaced all five `structure`'s with `class`'s, replaced all `(self : W. ...)` with `[W. ...]`, removed all `include self` and `self.`, and it seems to work fine (and a lot shorter!). Maybe you have an application in mind that is annoying without the dot notation?

If you don't need dot notation, the more natural thing is to remove the namespaces and replace `IsCharNeTwoNF.b₂` with `isCharNeTwoNF_b₂`, etc but maybe you still prefer the dot notation. I don't know which is better.

> Do you need long names and `haveI`'s? At least in this file, except for `IsCharThreeNF`, I replaced all five `structure`'s with `class`'s, replaced all `(self : W. ...)` with `[W. ...]`, removed all `include self` and `self.`, and it seems to work fine (and a lot shorter!). Maybe you have an application in mind that is annoying without the dot notation?

I mean outside this file. For example, if you know that a curve is in `IsShortNF`, either by input arguments (`(H : W.IsShortNF)` vs `[W.IsShortNF]`) or by prove it (`have H : W.IsShortNF := by ...` vs `haveI : W.IsShortNF := by ...`). The `structure` and `class` approach make no much difference. Suppose you want to use its properties. For the first case, you write `rw [H.XX]`. For the second case, you need to write `rw [IsShortNF.XX]` or `rw [XX_of_isShortNF]`, which is longer. And you need to remember what normal form you have used.

Moreover, do you think it's a good idea to make `IsShortNF.XX` as simp lemmas? In this way the above `rw` can simply be `simp [H]`. But I'm afraid that this may confuse simp system for `class` approach if you have proved that the curve are in several normal forms. 

> If you don't need dot notation, the more natural thing is to remove the namespaces and replace `IsCharNeTwoNF.b₂` with `isCharNeTwoNF_b₂`, etc but maybe you still prefer the dot notation. I don't know which is better.

Both of the approach will make the `rw` longer. For the first case you can `open IsCharNeTwoNF in` but then you get too many `b₂`.

Good point on the longer `rw`, but also good point on the `simp`-able lemmas. Could you try the `class` approach and make `IsShortNF.XX` simp lemmas? If the simpNF linter complains, then let's stick to your original `structure` approach, but otherwise I like the `class` approach. I'm convinced either way though!
I've changed it into typeclass, but I'm not sure `simp` works correctly... sometimes I need to manually specify which theorem to be used since it confuses the order.

One line:
```suggestion
  rw [self.isCharNeTwoNF.b₂, self.a₂, mul_zero]
```

One line but longer:
```suggestion
  rw [self.isCharNeTwoNF.b₈, self.a₂, mul_zero, zero_mul, zero_sub]
```
Alternatively you can remove the last three lemmas by changing `rw` to `simp`.

In fact you can do the same for `c₄`, `c₆`, and `Δ` below and `b₂` above.

You can insert the `rw` into the normalisation:
```suggestion
  linear_combination (norm := (rw [self.c₄]; ring1)) -16 * W.a₄ * CharP.cast_eq_zero R 3
```
I do this a lot to make things one line, but feel free to ignore this.

The same for the lemmas below.
But this makes the proof less readable...

In most other places you put "there is an explicit..." but here you put "this is a..."?
```suggestion
/-- There is an explicit change of variables of a `WeierstrassCurve` to
```
Same for `toCharNeTwoThreeNF`.

For some reason this works:
```suggestion
  erw [variableChange_comp]
  constructor <;> simp
```

I think it's better to call this `IsCharThreeJZeroNF` to match `IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF` (analogous to the difference between `IsCharTwoJZeroNF` and `IsCharTwoJNeZeroNF`).

Personally I find the names slightly confusing, because this is the normal form for both characteristic not 3 and characteristic 3 but j = 0. Arguably you could give them your own names e.g. `IsNF(B|C)(1|2)` based on Silverman's numbering in Appendix A, or `IsNF(A.)*` etc based on the parameters killed off. I don't know if this is a good idea, but I also don't have any better suggestions, so feel free to ignore this.

Another idea is to call it `IsShortNF` because Silverman calls it the "short Weierstrass form" a few times in contrast to the "long Weierstrass form". Then `IsCharNeTwoNF` can also be `IsMediumNF` if that sounds better?
I think `IsShortNF` is good. But I'm not sure about `IsCharNeTwoNF -> IsMediumNF`.
I'm happy with `IsShortNF` and we can keep `IsCharNeTwoNF` too. I guess `IsShort` is outrageous? ;)
`IsShort` -> Time is short 🤣

```suggestion
  of form $Y^2 = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$. It is the normal form of characteristic ≠ 2 or 3.
```

If you decide to call this `WeierstrassCurve.IsCharThreeJZeroNF` then you should rearrange the sentences.

You don't need `simpa`:
```suggestion
  simp [self.isCharNeTwoNF.b₄, self.a₄]
```
The same for the other lemmas below.

```suggestion
  rwa [E.coe_Δ', self.Δ_of_char_three, mul_ne_zero_iff] at h
```

```suggestion
  of form $Y^2 = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$. It is the normal form of characteristic ≠ 2 or 3, and
  also the normal form of characteristic = 3 and j = 0.
```

```suggestion
  See also `WeierstrassCurve.toShortNF` and `WeierstrassCurve.toShortNF_spec`.
```

```suggestion
  See also `WeierstrassCurve.toCharNeTwoNF` and `WeierstrassCurve.toCharNeTwoNF_spec`.
```

This is probably clearer and follows the sentence structure above:
```suggestion
  If the ring is of characteristic = 3, then for any `WeierstrassCurve` with $b_2 = 0$ (for an elliptic curve,
```
Same with the three others below.

```suggestion
  See also `WeierstrassCurve.toCharThreeNF` and `WeierstrassCurve.toCharThreeNF_spec`.
```

```suggestion
  See also `WeierstrassCurve.toCharTwoNF` and `WeierstrassCurve.toCharTwoNF_spec`.
```

```suggestion
  $Y^2 + a_3Y = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$. It is the normal form of characteristic = 2.
```
I guess you can add b2, b6, and b8 too here for completeness? Same for the others for `_char_two`.
Added.
I guess you want these in `Weierstrass.lean`? Maybe add it for Delta/j and char 3 too if they're nice enough.

> I guess you want these in `Weierstrass.lean`?

Yes. But I just checked that the file `Weierstrass.lean` does not import `CharP`...
OK, added a new file.

I think this is probably fine:
```suggestion
import Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.CharP
```
But more importantly, do you think we should split this from `Weierstrass.lean`? I don't feel like `CharP` is that huge of an import... What else do you picture would live in this new file?
It's OK for me to just put these results into `Weierstrass.lean`.

```suggestion
lemma Δ_of_char_two : W.Δ = W.a₁ ^ 4 * W.b₈ + W.a₃ ^ 4 + W.a₁ ^ 3 * W.a₃ ^ 3 := by
```

```suggestion
/-- A variant of `EllipticCurve.j_eq_zero_iff_of_char_two` without assuming a reduced ring. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- A variant of `EllipticCurve.j_eq_zero_iff_of_char_three` without assuming a reduced ring. -/
```

Seems like this `erw` was needed because of the `*` in the definition, which you could replace it with an explicit `VariableChange.comp`. Then this is just:
```suggestion
  rw [toCharThreeNF, variableChange_comp]
```
Same for `toShortNF` and `toShortNF_spec`. Do you think this is just due to missing API?

> Do you think this is just due to missing API?

Yes. I have a plan to refactor `VariableChange` to in favor of `*` instead of `VariableChange.comp`. For now let's just stick to `VariableChange.comp`.

If you replace `*` above with `VariableChange.comp`, then you can remove the `erw` here:
```suggestion
  rw [toCharThreeNF, toShortNFOfCharThree_a₂, hb₂, div_zero, ← VariableChange.id,
    VariableChange.id_comp]
```
I think having `erw`'s is one of the technical debts on Zulip.

I'm not a fan of making the values of defs or lemmas in the same line as the statement, but you did this for `toCharTwoJZeroNF`, so might as well be consistent since they're both short enough:
```suggestion
def toCharNeTwoNF : VariableChange R := ⟨1, 0, ⅟2 * -W.a₁, ⅟2 * -W.a₃⟩
```

```suggestion
This is the normal form of characteristic ≠ 2 or 3, and
```
This definition doesn't seem to assume j = 0? Same for `toShortNFOfCharThree` and `toCharTwoJZeroNF`.
The definition itself does not require j = 0. The condition j = 0 is only used when proving its properties.

Move this to the section below, and remove `(W : WeierstrassCurve F)` since it's already declared.

Don't need `section` since `(W : WeierstrassCurve F)` will die when you close `VariableChange`.

Move this to the section below, and remove `(W : WeierstrassCurve F)` since it's already declared.

Don't need `section` since `(W : WeierstrassCurve F)` will die when you close `VariableChange`.

One line shorter:
```suggestion
  set W' := W.variableChange W.toShortNFOfCharThree
  have H : W'.IsCharNeTwoNF := W.toCharNeTwoNF_spec
  constructor
  · simp [H.a₁]
  · simp [H.a₁, H.a₃]
  · field_simp [W.toShortNFOfCharThree_a₂ ▸ hb₂]
    linear_combination (W'.a₄ * W'.a₂ ^ 2 + W'.a₄ ^ 2) * CharP.cast_eq_zero F 3
```

Consistency:
```suggestion
there is an explicit change of variables of it to $Y^2 = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$
```

Consistency:
```suggestion
there is an explicit change of variables of it to $Y^2 + a_3Y = X^3 + a_4X + a_6$
```

Consistency:
```suggestion
there is an explicit change of variables of it to $Y^2 + XY = X^3 + a_2X^2 + a_6$
```

```suggestion
/-- A `WeierstrassCurve` is in normal form of characteristic = 2 and j ≠ 0, if its $a_1 = 1$ and
```
Do `-` render properly? I use ` *` (indented with one space) for bullets usually.
I think yes; see for example https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/FieldTheory/SeparableDegree.lean

Extract `[CharP R 3]` into a variable outside since it's used multiple times here?

Same with those in `IsCharThreeJNeZero` (both `W` and `E`) and `IsCharTwoJNeZero`.

Do you want this too?
```
theorem j : E.j = -110592 * E.a₄ ^ 3 / (-64 * E.a₄ ^ 3 - 27 * E.b₆ ^ 2) := by
  have h := E.Δ'.ne_zero
  rw [E.coe_Δ', self.Δ] at h
  rw [EllipticCurve.j, Units.val_inv_eq_inv_val, ← div_eq_inv_mul, E.coe_Δ',
    self.c₄, self.Δ, div_eq_div_iff h h]
  ring1
```
I just copied this from `IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF`, but you can probably make the proof nicer.
Nice observation! I think this is similar to that of `IsShortNF`.

I saw that you made a post on Zulip if this should be `[DecidableEq F]` or `open scoped Classical in`, and you decided on the former, because you want them to be computable if `F` is a computable field. This is more of a question for my sanity: should I do the same for things like point addition if I could?

> This is more of a question for my sanity: should I do the same for things like point addition if I could?

It's up to you. Personally I think `DecidableEq` is better. (Perhaps in some day Lean can be a number theory CAS with these algorithms.)
Presumably you can't do `[DecidableEq]` for `exists_variableChange_isCharTwoNF`?

> Presumably you can't do `[DecidableEq]` for `exists_variableChange_isCharTwoNF`?

It's also possible. Will change it.

```suggestion
theorem toCharThreeNF_spec_of_b₂_eq_zero (hb₂ : W.b₂ = 0) :
```
But do you think we need to rename `XXXJZero -> XXXJEqZero`? In my opinion, `JEqZero` is too long...

Yeah I'm also a bit torn about this. I prefer changing `JZero` to `JEqZero` because `J` isn't a keyword used in other places in mathlib, unlike `Char` which is standard. I'm happy with either, but this lemma can be `_eq_zero` regardless.
Changed.

```suggestion
  · simp [toCharTwoJZeroNF]
    linear_combination 2 * W.a₂ * CharP.cast_eq_zero R 2
```
But this will introduce a non-terminating `simp`, which is discouraged in mathlib if I remembered correctly.
Sure, but in many places you have `field_simp` followed by `linear_combination`, and if I recall correctly `field_simp` calls all of `simp` in addition to those specifically tagged with `field_simp`.
I think a compromise is write `simp_rw [toCharTwoJEqZeroNF, variableChange_a₂, inv_one, Units.val_one]` instead of `simp [toCharTwoJZeroNF]`.

I just found [this](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/.60simp.60.20followers) where they discuss what's OK after a `simp`, and I'd argue that `linear_combination` is basically `ring`.

I also just found [this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/b758def5262ecb106a626ec885176ed1ece2e4ba/scripts/lint-style.py#L154) which are the tactics that are OK after a `simp`, which includes `ring`.

> I also just found [this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/b758def5262ecb106a626ec885176ed1ece2e4ba/scripts/lint-style.py#L154) which are the tactics that are OK after a `simp`, which includes `ring`.

Interesting. But that is not including `linear_combination`...
Yeah, and I'm advocating for it to be included on Zulip right now :P

The consensus so far is that `field_simp` shouldn't be used before `linear_combination` (and might be added to the flexible list soon); instead we should use `field_simp only` which perhaps someone is working on.

> The consensus so far is that `field_simp` shouldn't be used before `linear_combination` (and might be added to the flexible list soon); instead we should use `field_simp only` which perhaps someone is working on.

Oh, that's a bad news... I remembered that `field_simp; ...` is also used in e.g. `Weierstrass.lean` and other files. What about `suffices ...; field_simp ...`?

In my opinion the default `field_simp` should only do `ring` + `field_simp` lemmas. But I think non-terminal `ring` is also discouraged, right?

Yeah it's bad news but I do agree with it somewhat, and non-terminal `ring` is indeed discouraged. To be honest `Weierstrass.lean`, `Affine.lean`, and `Group.lean` were written a long time ago and I have since learnt how to write better Lean. For now we don't have `field_simp only`, so let's just keep it as you have written.
Oops, one last thing: what happens if you don't give them names? Are the self-generated names terrible?
I haven't checked yet, but I prefer to give them explicit names; that's not harmful, right? Also, I referenced them in the docstring, so explicit names are preferred.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/NormalForms): some normal forms of elliptic curves

  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>
```

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Thanks for this! I added some very basic comments. I note that this is somewhat similar to the `ModelsWithJ` section in `Weierstrass.lean` in the sense that you defined explicit forms of Weierstrass curves for specific purposes.

Do you intend to add a lot more to this file (e.g. characteristic 2, characteristic not 2 or 3, and maybe the isomorphism on the group of points)? If that's the case, do you think you can repurpose this into a file about isomorphisms induced by variable changes (maybe `Equiv.lean`?). A while ago, you added quite a bit of stuff on variable changes that's sprinkled everywhere in `Weierstrass.lean`, but maybe it's time to extract them into a separate file. Arguably, the main content of this file is the variable change rather than the Prop, unless you have something else you want to prove for the Prop?

> Do you intend to add a lot more to this file (e.g. characteristic 2, characteristic not 2 or 3

Yes, My first plan is to add four normal forms with respect to characteristics, listed in Silverman's GTM106. In later PRs we may eventually add Legendre forms, etc.

> maybe the isomorphism on the group of points)? If that's the case, do you think you can repurpose this into a file about isomorphisms induced by variable changes (maybe `Equiv.lean`?).

Not yet, at least not in this PR and in this file. They should be in another (upstream) file anyway.

> A while ago, you added quite a bit of stuff on variable changes that's sprinkled everywhere in `Weierstrass.lean`, but maybe it's time to extract them into a separate file.

I agree, maybe the basic property of variable changes should go to `VariableChange/Basic.lean`. In this way it imports minimal files. In my opinion, the isomorphism of points induced by variable changes should go to a downstream file, since it imports more files.

> Arguably, the main content of this file is the variable change rather than the Prop, unless you have something else you want to prove for the Prop?

No, I think the main contents of this file `NormalForms.lean` are these Props and their corollaries (for example, what is the `j`-invariant, listed in Silverman's GTM106, section III.1 and Appendix A), together with the existence of variable changes (explicit, if applicable, but only merely existence does not harm) to transform a Weierstrass equation to these forms.

Thanks! Some minor nitpicks on the docstring, but otherwise LGTM

bors d+

:v: acmepjz can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
This became a pretty long PR as itself, but the definitions and theorems are very structured with good docstrings :) I added a few basic comments and will go in-depth tomorrow.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/*): split `VariableChange` into a new file

nodes.body: Had almost no time today! Some minor suggestions.

Thanks for your patience! I added lots of mostly stylistic comments for the first half. My main suggestion is to rename `IsCharNeTwoThreeNF` (either to `IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF`, or to your own custom name, maybe even `IsShortNF`?). I will finish the second half tomorrow.

> My main suggestion is to rename `IsCharNeTwoThreeNF` (either to `IsCharThreeJNeZeroNF`, or to your own custom name, maybe even `IsShortNF`?).

I think `IsShortNF` is better, since it is the normal form of 2 cases, one is char not 2 or 3, another one is char 3 and j = 0.
Some docstring comments. I will finish the rest tomorrow (I swear!)
Thanks for your patience! I'm happy with this PR once all the changes are made.
LGTM! Thanks for your patience

Thanks for the review!

bors r+
Oh I didn't actually check the `@[simp]` tags you added later, but I trust that you made them work somehow.

> Oh I didn't actually check the `@[simp]` tags you added later, but I trust that you made them work somehow.

In fact very few of them were added, as there are a lot of `not in simp normal form` error: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11160554198/job/31021240436. Perhaps some of the `@[simp]` tags should be removed since they didn't simplify things significantly; we can remove them later if it is indeed the case.
